aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Incident Analysis - Airbus Helicopters AS350 Hydraulic System Failure
The incident occurred in Clewiston, Florida.
The incident occurred on May 3, 2020, at 13:15 Local time.
The aircraft involved was an Airbus Helicopters AS350.
The defining event was flight control system malfunction/failure.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The incident number was ENG20LA031.
The aircraft registration was N1WT.
The aircraft sustained no damage.
There was 1 person onboard who sustained no injuries.
The No. 2 hydraulic system is referred to as HYD2.
The HYD2 pulley bearing likely failed due to being installed skewed onto its pulley.
The skewed installation resulted in abnormal bearing loads.
The abnormal bearing loads led to premature failure of the HYD2 pulley bearing.
Plastic deformation was observed on the bearing raceways and rolling elements.
Contact damage was observed on the bearing cage.
The damage was consistent with sliding of the rolling elements against the raceways and cage.
The sliding was due to abnormal loading and forced rotation of a seized bearing.
The seizure of the HYD2 pulley bearing led to the deterioration of the drive belt.
The deterioration resulted in the drive belt's failure.
The drive belt failure caused loss of hydraulic pressure in HYD2.
Loss of hydraulic assistance from HYD2 included the tail rotor servo control.
The loss of hydraulic assistance resulted in higher pedal forces to control the helicopter in the yaw axis.
The HYD2 pulley bearing likely did not show obvious visual evidence of deterioration during past inspections.
The last scheduled inspection occurred about 13 flight hours prior to the incident.
Visual detection of the deteriorating bearing may not have been possible without removal of the bearing from the pulley.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of this incident.
The probable cause was seizure of the hydraulic pump pulley bearing due to its improper installation by the manufacturer.
The improper installation led to a failure of the hydraulic pump belt.
The hydraulic pump belt failure resulted in partial loss of hydraulic assistance to the pedals.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Clewiston, Florida

## Date & Time: 
May 3, 2020, 13:15 Local

## Aircraft:
Airbus Helicopters AS350

## Defining Event:
Flight control sys malf/fail

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Incident Number:
ENG20LA031

## Registration:
N1WT

## Aircraft Damage:
None

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The No. 2 hydraulic system (HYD2) pulley bearing likely failed due to being installed skewed onto its pulley, resulting in abnormal bearing loads which led to its premature failure. The plastic deformation observed on the raceways and rolling elements, as well as contact damage on the bearing cage, were consistent with sliding of the rolling elements against the raceways and cage due to abnormal loading and forced rotation of a seized bearing.

The seizure of the HYD2 pulley bearing led to the deterioration of the drive belt, resulting in its failure and the subsequent loss of hydraulic pressure in HYD2. Loss of hydraulic assistance from HYD2, which included the tail rotor servo control, resulted in higher pedal forces to control the helicopter in the yaw axis. It is likely the HYD2 pulley bearing did not show obvious visual evidence of deterioration during past inspections, including the last scheduled inspection about 13 flight hours prior to the incident, and visual detection of the deteriorating bearing may not have been possible without removal of the bearing from the pulley.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this incident to be:

Seizure of the hydraulic pump pulley bearing due to its improper installation by the manufacturer, leading to a failure of the hydraulic pump belt and the resultant partial loss of hydraulic assistance to the pedals.

---
